awd_titl_txt: Investigation of the Adhesion of Enteromorpha clathrata and the Consequent Hydrodynamic Forces on Underwater Vehicles   and Structures
awd_abstract_narration: This work involves the investigation of the adhesive                            characteristic of two principal fouling organisms, namely,                      Enteromorpha intestinalis and Ectocarpus spp. that adhere                       to underwater ocean vessels and structures, the resulting                       formation on the surfaces and the consequent changes in                         hydrodynamic forces.  The study therefore will take shape                       in three phases.  The first is to establish the time                            varying adhesion of the organisms as a function of surface                      and environmental conditions, including factors that                            influence adhesion.  Secondly, to develop a model of the                        fouled surface as a function of time, surface and                               environmental conditions.  And finally, the work includes                       the use of the modeled surface to analytically formulate a                      method to better predict changes in hydrodynamic forces                         caused by fouling.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems
